text: Pours hazy mahogany with a nice buff head. Aroma features caramel and toasted malt. Flavor echoes the aroma while adding a little more sweetness. Mouthfeel offers good fizz and body. Happy Anniversary.

Dark brown with a taller, dense, light ecru colored head. Dark brown sugar, toasted malt and hints of darker fruit. Lightly sweet, middle has a bit of spice and herbal character. Mild candi, toasted malt and light yeast and dough in the finish. Clean, simple Dubbel. 1/13

(Last) 500 ml bottle from the brewery (2013), sampled at cellar temperature from a Chouffe tulip. Still a fairly big pop as the cap comes off - good sign - and the pour is a beautiful creamy light tan mass of foam that tops a darkly translucent, almost opaque walnut body, leaving very thick chunks as it very slowly dissipates...aroma is a mixture of vinous, lightly tart and oxidized notes with the caramel-banana aspects of a dunkelweizen, along with some coffee and chocolate - lots of dark roastiness here...body is mostly sweet at the front with some light tingly spiciness, like cinnamon in coffee, roastiness growing towards a somewhat drier finish...low to medium warming alcohol presence throughout, body slightly on the thin side at this point, carbonation starting to disappear though theres still just enough to keep things pleasant. This was at its best fresh - the bottle I had a year later had gone downhill a bit, and the one last year was getting rather sour and off; strangely its improved for this last sample, which makes me wish that I had somehow managed to attain more than a four-pack. Oh well, good memories.

Sample shared @ RBWG Tampa. Thanks to whoever brought this! Amber pour with a small off-white head. Nose is has some toast and croissant. A bit of caramel, baked apples. Flavor is nicely balanced - sweet grain, mellow toastiness. Soft fruit. Light earth. Eminently drinkable. Medium body, soft carb.

Bottle at the RBWG 2015 Grand Tasting. Pours cloudy amber with a foamy, off-white head. Sugary and bready malts define this one, along with a bit of caramel, brown sugar. Mild ripe orange. Medium to full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Pretty drinkable stuff. Tasty.
Old rating. I've had this twice and never rated, huh? Well I remember a mash of banana Belgian and booze. A little muddled. Maybe aged it would settle.

Bottled.Old note. Aroma has spice tones, lots of earthy yeast, toffee. Bit hazy, amber coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is light sweet, light bitter, has earth, toffee and quite some spice.
This tastes and smells like a strong ale had sex with a dunkelweizen and this popped out. Banana and booze and malt with a bit of minerally water taste and a slight bitter hoppiness at the end.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2015 Bottle at RBWG 15 Grand Tasting @ Coppertail, thanks to whomever shared this one, 21/02/15. 
Chestnut brown with a solid beige covering.
Nose is sweet caramel, dark fruit rinds, light spice, musty notes.
Taste comprises toffee, musty wood strokes, light spice, raisens, dark fruit notes.
Medium + body, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Ok offering.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Purchased illicitly in Michigan a few weeks back. Beige coupe on the side of the road, told the guy I was looking for a good time. Quite a bit of head, but Ive done worse for a beer.

Bottle at Coppertail Brewing during the RBWG 2015 Grand Tasting. Clear amber with off-white head. Aromas of light caramel, floral. Tastes of caramel, toffee, a bit vegetal. Medium body with a dry finish. Not quite what I expected for New Glarus.
Bottle - Light cocoa and dark fruit with a malty richness. Clear Amber with a nice light brown head. Malty, sweet and a bit of light ginger. Nice.

New Glarus 20th Anniv. strong ale.
Refined and aged (I presume), this pouts with a fine orange-brown body that has excellent clarity and is topped by a good head. The aroma suggest liquer at least as much as ale. The strong ale style (such as it is) comes out clearly upon tasting.

Bottle. Pour is medium clear brown with a small tan head. Aroma and flavor are light toasted malt, light clove, light banana, and a touch of spice. Its very clean and drinkable. Not overly complex but well done.

Bottle shared by Tanner with Zach and I. Pours a rather clear amber brown with a medium to large beige head. Soft toffee and caramel, light stone fruit. Medium bodied, sweet caramel, warm toffee. Light warming alcohol, soft caramel. Lovely and balanced gentle malt and spice. Very tasty.

Bottle. Thanks to mike12da. Apples and bubblegum in the nose. Light brown color. Strong grain, dark sugar, concentrated fruit, and a sudden bitterness in finish, seems a bit ashy. Medium body. Interesting stuff. Moderate fruitiness and bittering to match.
Bottle. Brown-orange color. Nose of caramel, oranges, rather tangy. Tangy flavor of chocolate, orange, pears. Almost tart. A bit light in body, with good, juicy malts and fruit flavors.
bottle to glass; drank this without knowing style and wouldnt have guessed dubbel - dark fruit and caramel in aroma - taste was more complex but it did get overly sweet after a few sips..
15 Sept 2014, bottle. brown and hazy. nose is sweet, bread yeast. med/thin body and moderately fizzy. sugary, bread malt, some syrup, noticeable alcohol, maybe hints of grape jelly. pretty good
Sample at first sunday. Earthy and chocolatey aroma. Bourbon and fruit flavors. Lots of roaty malt. Gritty texture with dirty earthy notes on the finish. Red fruit, plum, cherry.

500 ml bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of caramel, fruitiness and a hint of earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of caramel, fruitiness and light earthiness with a smooth lingering fruity finish.

Pours a burgundy with a solid rocky head. Nose is ripe banana, clove, nutty, some burnt sugars, a bit of alcohol heat, almost a banana pudding thing going on, sweetness. Taste is molasses, burnt sugars, a raisin/prune bit of booze, over-ripe banana, a metallic thing especially on the very finish like I licked a spoon. It's fine, but not really impressive. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of Motortoddhead. Pours a deep russet brown with a large fluffy cream colored head. Aroma of figs, dates, banana, cloves and biscotti cookies. Taste of biscotti, cloves, light banana, and figs.

Bottle... Clear mahogany pour with a small, creamy, off-white head. The aromatics provide caramel and a whisper of sassafras root. Medium to full-bodied with tingly carbonation. The flavor leans bitter, offering notes of toasted malts and sassafras. Finishes bitter and tongue numbing (like Novocain). Odd bird, this one. Weird esters and/or phenols, but not at all unpleasant. Bottle courtesy of FlandersNed!

This one poured a dark red to brown with a fluffy beige head. Aroma was of dark fruits, toast, and chocolate. Flavor was similar, a bit in the sweet and boozy side which is kind of disappointing from these guys.

Bottle 500ml. [ As New Glarus Anniversary Strong Ale ].Clear medium to dark amber color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, caramel, sweet malt, candy, light belgium yeast - fruity - candy - dried fruit, light honey, light alcohol. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet with a long duration, sweet malt, candy, honey, light begium yeast. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20140222]

Rating 2300...woohoo!! Bottle poured into a shaker. Pours cola brown with a finger of light khaki head. Aroma of caramel, some bright red berries, clove and banana. Taste is light sweet, follows aroma. Wow, very boozy. Full bodied with a thick texture. Lively carbonation and a very long, warming finish. Pretty darn good. Wish I knew the abv on this guys, its gotta be up there.

Bottle, thnx to Summer Santa 2013. Pours a clear brownish amber beer with a nice, firm off white head on top that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, earthy yeasty esters, nutty presences and leaves. Smells like autumn. Flavor is moderatly sweet, loads of fruity yeasty stuff going on and very big malty caramel base in the back. Very nicely balanced, lots of things going on and in my opinion is this the way a Dubbel should be. Nice and sweet, light cloying mouthfeel. Soft carbo, great drinkability. I think the abv must be around the 7-8.5 range judging by the cloying sweetness. Very nice surprise!

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ø - pours nice brown colour with a off-white head. Sweet malty aroma and taste, caramel, toffee,butterscotch, brown sugar, syrup, light yeasty spice in there as well. Nice.
Bottle share in 2013. Dark brown with a medium off-white head. Aroma is faint - yeast, dark fruit, sweet malt. Flavor is similar with spice and herbal hops making an appearance.

The beer is russet brown with a thick, billowing off-white head. the aroma brings typical New Glarus sweetness, with some molasses, malt, candied fruits, yeast, sugars. Its not as sweet as I feared, and is actually quite tasty. Complex and well balanced. Easy drinking and smooth. I split this beer with a friend and we both had no problem finishing our pours. Well crafted. Id have this again.

Bottle @ home. Thanks, Jake. Dark amber pour with a tall khaki head. Smells of prune, plum, chocolate, and banana. Some clove, a bit of raisin, and lots of biscuit dough and burnt sugar. Really sweet flavor of raisin, black cherry, and plums. Banana, sweet chocolate syrup, and a bit of clove. Not bad, just very sweet and lots of candied fruit.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty spicy caramel aroma with weak yeasty and weak hoppy hints. Sweetish malty spicy weak yeasty caramel flavor with some hoppy bitter hints. Has a fruity malty spicy bitter caramel finish.
Nothing spectacular. Fairly run of the mill considering its from New Glarus.

had a couple of times of the month .. . pours a monk butt brown .. . foam is really good .. . mild brown bread, raisin, and booze .. . very underwhelming, a bit disappointing .. . . If you dont get the attention you desperately crave from the ones you love... Get meaningless attention from strangers. It works for me.

Bottle:
Pours cola brown, thin, off-white head.
Cherry Coke, fruit, alcohol aroma.
Taste is sweet, caramel malt, cherries, bread.
Very good.
Pronounced alcohol warmth and taste.

Deep caramel brown in color... Aroma of berries, caramel, dark fruits, belgian candi sugar... Flavor is candi sugar, berries, plum, caramel, hint of alcohol... Really smooth... Great beer

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. Dark amber coloured. Unclear. Dense light beige head. Aroma. Sweetness, berries, caramel, bread. Flavour. Caramel, bread, sweetness, some berries. Medium to full bodied. Ends full of berries and sweetness. NIce.

Bottle at Papsø.
Clear orange-red coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of caramel, marzipan and dried fruits.
Sweet and fruity flavour of caramel, hops and marzipan with notes of alcohol.
Sweet and hoppy finish.
50 cl bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small off white head. Aroma is toasted malty and breadish. Breadish, mild metallic and roasted malty. Dry and almost herbal finish.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours an almost clear orangey brown with a lacing, beige head. Sweet, brown sugar aroma with some Belgian yeast. Rich body, lovely complex fruit esters from the yeast, again brown sugar, some friendly phenols. An amazing Dubbel. 220414

Pours dark amber with etched top. Smells like fruity, alcohol, some belgian sugar, some malts. Flavor is a little metal, some alcohol, some more fruity notes - stoney. Medium on light bodied with sparkly carb and a dry finish. I think this beer would benefit from time.
From the 500 ml bottle. Big strong ale/almost Trappist flavors and notes. A bit chewy with nice malt and sugar base.
Bottle (Courtesy of the great D.F.). Cherry and toffee malt aroma. Chestnut with large off-white head. Sweet toffee malt, tart cherry, and alcohol flavor. Pretty good.
Bottle as shown thanks to Will. Pours a murky light brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is wet biscuit and bready malt. Medium mouthfeel with light bready malt and roast. Good.

Bottle courtesy of dmbforever (a great BA trader). Shared at Proof for HH. Deep amber brown in color with a really good amount of tan head that holds up well. Head faded into a medium-thin collar and good swirls of head. Aroma is earthy floral, some light brown sugar, vanilla. Great medium body and highly carbonated. Taste has fig and brown sugar throughout. Light bitterness in the middle. Sweet fig up front. Very interesting, a bit odd, but extremely enjoyable.

Bottle thanks to trade. Pours a hazy amber with a light yellowish brown that dissipates slowly to the edges and laces. Aroma has a good amount of Belgian yeast with sweet bread and some light fruits. Flavor has the same sweet bread note with light fruits and Belgian yeast as well as a hint of earthiness.

500ml bottle thanks to MOTORHEADTODD. Poured an ugly muddy brown with a fuller foamy beige head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, chocolate, nuts, sweet sugar, dark toast, alcohol. Full body with strogn carbonation and an average to long lasting duration on the aftertaste. Notes of sugar, darker chocolate, dark dry toast, nuts, and some more lightly sweet chocolate. Overall not impressed.

Thanks to my little brother from the same mother (and father for that matter) deadCATAtlanta for sharing with me. Pours a hazy dark tan with large lasting off white head. Scent is bread, booze, and dark grapes. Flavor starts earthy, then turns barely bitter, and finishes a pleasant sweetness. Medium bodied with near perfect level of carbonation. Bottle - Shared by deadCATAtlanta

Sat on my shelf for 6 months, finally cracked it open. Pours a beautiful ruby red, dark brown. Thin white head. Nose is rich Dubbel spice, almonds. Huge flavor, like drinking gingersnap cookie dough, hazelnuts, prevalent banana, hint of black licorice, and even a little milk chocolate. Would have given this a 4+, but there was a  slight metallic taste that lingered at the finish. Otherwise just terrific, rich, substantial beer.

The first NG beer I didnt finish, this was just too packed full of some flavor I couldnt get past, it was like vinuous taste on the back of the tongue just unrelenting in its grip.. like when you eat a bitter piece of vegetable.

Bottle of course. Brown appearance and well carbonated even for being aroind six months old. Classic flavors amd aromas of a dubbel in the line of a Rochefort or Prior 8. Sweet and lots of malt. First rate dubbel.

In short: A smooth toasted Dubbel-style ale. Unexciting but very drinkable.
How: Bottle shared at post HF FoFA 2013 party.
The look: Dark brown body topped by a small beige head.
In long: Timid nose of toasted bread, browned banana peels and mild phenolic notes. In mouth the beer has a medium body with a lively carbonation. Taste is not exciting. There is basic toasted bread with caramel spread. Yeasty notes. Some notes. Mild fruity notes of ripe bananas and figs. A light spiciness. This was a rather smooth beer that maybe suffered because it was served during a tasting where most beers were very intense. And dont tell me I was the most disgusting person at the tasting because I kept asking people if I could pee in their glass, I wasnt, the two persons who said yes were.

Bottle. The pour is a dark carmel color with a thick head. The aroma is mild and similar to a lager. The taste is very nice. Mild and was expecting more booze, but very easy drinking. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I love this style, nutty and dry, clean , this is amazing, so clean and delicious

Darkish cloudy red brown. Strong banana aroma. Bitter, then strong sweetness. Forward alcohol, heavy body, very clean palate. Not as much complexity as some other New Glarus beers, but still well balanced.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2014 16.9 oz./500 ml. bottle shared and poured to snifters showing a dark mahogany color, a modest layer of off white foam that diminished expeditiously to a bubbly ring & film, while leaving some waves & spots on the glass. The aroma was immediately banana candy/circus peanuts, then malty sweetness, caramel, light spice, and dark & dried fruit as currants & plum. The flavor incorporated a lingering hop bitterness that was a bit rindy and somewhat forceful for this malt centric style. Medium bodied, with a pleasant dryness to the finish. A decent Dubbel. Another shared bottle poured to snifters, adding a bit of cherry to the nose, lively carbonation, and a healthy alcohol presence that warmed.

Thanks Adam for the bottle. Shared with a friend. Poured with a toffee appearance. nose was sweet peaches and figs.This was pretty good. Very much in line to style, slightly sticky, not sweet for a long time. Nice oak and yeasty bread / biscuit presence.

Bottle at Exira Beer Summit IV. Thanks to adnielsen for bringing the bottle. Pours a brown color with white head. Tangy, malty, toffee aromas. Tangy, brown sugar, malty, candi sugar flavors. Alright, but nothing that blows my mind.
Light brown, clear, beige head. Aroma: grainy, bready malt, fruity notes. Flavor:  bready malt, caramel, dark fruit, nutty notes.
Poured from a 500ml bottle. Big malty beer. Slightly yeasty, prune, plum, melanoidin rich, hot alcohol in the nose. Good beer.

500 mL bottle. Deep ruby brown with a large beige head. Aroma is of raisin, candy sugar, caramel, pumpernickel, and roasted malts. Taste is of licorice, raisin, brown sugar, brandy, candy sugar, and caramel.
Bottle. The look is a beige head, clear, reddish brown in color. The smell is raisin, malt, fruit, yeast, prunes, and good. The taste is yeast, fruits, spiced, belgian, and ok.

Pours a dark cloudy mahogany with a thick, fluffy khaki 2 finger head with some good lacing. Aromas of clove, yeast, hint of banana, fig, a little alcohol. Quite effervescent on the tongue but not too much, tastes of clove, dark bready malt, a little bitterness in the tail end that flushes away. Good brew, worthy of an anniversary ale.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep reddish caramel, moderate foamy tannish head, somewhat nice lacing. &nbsp Bready nose, a little figgy. &nbsp Has some banana to it. &nbsp Smooth on the tongue, a little chewy. &nbsp Clean, dark bready fruitiness &nbsp Not a lot of musty or barnish notes. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp More fruity than most, less bready and musty. &nbsp Good, but wished it were a bit more bright.
Clear copper with a thin tan crown. Aroma of toffee, Munich malts, noble hops, faint dark fruits and grains. Taste of toffee, dark fruits, pale malts and faint yeast. Sweet and sticky, okay.

10/13/13. Bottle shared by Adam and Matt. Dark amber pour with a small khaki head. Boozy aroma, sweet malts, dark fruits, dark sugars, more alcohol. Burning alcohol flavor, lots of sweet malts, mild roast, a touch of oxidation, boozy. Meh.

Dark red pour with a white head. The aroma has some light smoke and caramel notes. The flavor is full of smoke, caramel and toffee. It also has a slight medicinal character and some alcohol. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Dark brown pour with off white head, Aroma of rich sweet malt and caramel. Very sweet slightly alcohol full flavor. Pretty delicious ale and full body finish.
Bottle from brewery. Definitely strong. Better as it settled out and warmed up a bit. Very tasty once I got accustomed to it. Strong beer.

500ml bottle. Aroma of sweet, dark malts, dried fruit, berry and mild yeast spice, some faint banana esters and toffee as well. Clear dark amber-brown in color with a lasting, fine, uneven head, very nice lacing. This is bottle-conditioned, however, as the second pour revealed a dusting of sediment. Flavor profile is fruity, malty and somewhat sweet, with notes of mild chocolate, raisin and spice bread, finishing with more of the banana esters and a faint earthiness. Smooth, creamy and full on the palate, with a persistent but mild effervescence and a fairly big body. I enjoyed this. Cheers to NG for their first 20 years.

500 ml bottle. (New Glarus Brewery) New Glarus, WI.
Clear red brown colour with a big foamy light tan head. 
Mild yeast, mild chocolate, dark fruits, dry malt and hints of hops in the aroma. Not bad. 
The flavour is yeast, alcohol, dark malt, mild sourness and mild hops. 
Strong. Warming. Im gonna be drunk soon...
Dark carmel color, lots of banana and belgian spice. This drinks much more like a belgian quad than the abbey double it claims.

500 ml bottle

Thanks to wnoble or tastybeer for sharing this over Labor Day weekend. It was a respectable anniversary ale with enough depth that it should last for a few years in the cellar. I look forward to sharing my own bottle with folks down the road. My only regret is not having the foresight to buy multiple when at the brewery.

Aroma / Appearance - An amber red base sticks around with an ivory head that is sticky and dense. Legs of sticky fluid sweep down the sides. Malts, sweet fruity aspects, and old hops hang in the air like the smell of damp rain.

Flavor / Palate - Caramel, malt, and warm alcohol stick in the throat with a mild heaviness. The beer itself feels fruity and sweet without being overwhelming. I actually thought of it more as an old ale than an abbey dubbel. That said it is worth trying if you happen to run across a bottle. Then again, when is a new release from Dan not worth sampling at least once?
Aroma is yeast, dark fruit and dry malts. The flavor is dark/toasted malts, grapes/dark fruit, slight tartness and a mix of sour and warming alcohol in the finish.

Shared with my brother in law, thanks Brant! Pours a dark amber with a small white head. Dark fruits in the nose with a hint of hops and alcohol. Great anniversary ale. Glad I got to try it. If you can find it, try it.
shared with jtclockwork-16.9oz bottle-lt tan-dk amber. A-med malt-caramel, some spice. T-follows.

Pours a rich mahogany umber color with a thick creamy foam that sticks like a boss. Nice soft aromas of dates, brown sugar, raisin and some spicy yeast esters. The palate follows with a smooth creamy mouthfeel and a soft burnt sugar sweetness, walnut bitterness. kiss of smoked malt, licorice and plums. Complex and tasty... looking forward to setting one in the cellar !
Bottle shared by Jcwattsrugger. Pours dark brown with off white head. Nose and taste of dark toffee, brown sugar, charred malt, smoked cherry wood and tobacco. Medium body. short finish.
Bottle from NG. Poured very dark red brown with huge head. Light yeast fruit aroma. Med carb and body. Hearty yeasty light hop taste.

500ml bottle in a tulip. Pours deep brown with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of spicy yeast, some dark fruits, a little chocolate, roast, and caramel from the malts, hints of alcohol, and light hops. Flavor the same. Average texture. A pretty good beer.

Very nice. Presumably a quad. A little light on the Belgian yeast, but dark fruit in abundance. Excessively drinkable. B+/A-

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle courtesy of Drake, thanks! clear amber maroon color, thick bright light tan head, solid lacing. Aroma of nutty toast, light nutella. Taste is sweet toffe, cocoa, light spice. Nice. I have a feeling it might age pretty well.

Half liter bottle courtesy of GhostFace and shared at the Baltimore Late Late Summer Gathering, 9/14/13. Pours a clear dark reddish-brown with a thin frothy white head. Good head retention. Aroma of banana, toffee, cinnamon, dark fruits, spicy finish. The taste is toffee malts, banana, spice, herbal hops, dark fruits, mild dried pineapple. Medium bodied, faint booze.

Thank you madbeerbaron! Real good. Didnt know what to expect from the label saying strong ale. Pours reddish brown with a big bubbly light tan head. Smell of Belgian yeast, sugar, and apricot. Light bubbly body that has a nice caramel candied sugar taste and a little roasted pecan ending. So many flavors from start to finish my beer is half gone to try and pick up the flavors.

500 ml bottle shared by phaleslu. Pours a slightly hazy dark amber/copper/brown color with a thin off white head. The aroma and flavor had the sweeter malts, caramel, brown sugar and fruits I would expect in a dubbel with additional notes of earth, herbal hints, wood, light spicy character. Opens sweet and finishes with the herbal, earthy, woody with an overall dryness. A touch of the alcohol comes through.

Bottle, as pictured, purchased from the brewery last month. Nice facility. Pours a hazy medium-shade of brown. Nice loooong lasting head. Smells fruity, lots of raisins. Taste is heavy on the Belgian yeast and sweet dark fruit. Pretty good example of the American version of the style.
Bottle pour. Dark copper with a beige head of foam. Aroma is pepper, caramel, fig, and molasses. Taste is a darker sweetness with a subtle spice persuasion. Tasty stuff.
Bottle. Copper pour, off-white head. Some retention/good lace. Aroma of fruity ester, fig, nuts, brown sugar. Taste is sweet, brown sugar. Palate is high carbonation, slick, sweet finish
Dark brown. Creamy, boozy but tasty. Toffee, spicy, raisiny. Not my style, but well made.
Bottle. Pours a dark mahogany color with a tan head. Aroma is bubblegum, Belgian yeast, candied sugar. Taste is sweet with a little smoke and bitterness. Medium bodied. Not bad.

Traded bottle. Pours a nice brown color with some bronze highlights and a bubbly white head; decent lacing. Aroma is all dark and sweet malts with a touch of yeast. Big, bold flavor of dark, syrupy fruit. Finishes a little boozey. Not listed but I bet the ABV is about 9.5. Pretty nice overall.
Pours a deep cloudy brown with off white fizzy head. Nose and taste are a bit of a muddled combo of malt, dark fruit, and leather. Its a good beer, I suspect it will be better in a year or five.

Dark appearance but clear burnt red exposed to light. Semi-frothy,light lace. Aroma is somewhat sweet and burnt malts,raison,chocolate.
 Tast has some dark sweet malts,bitter burnt nature,burnt/bitter finish-a little harsh, some hoppiness but more burnt malts,chocolate, with the sweet and bitter/burnt tones it comes across a little cloying or diety. Strong bitter/burnt finish-harsh.Strong carb. Not digging this overall or just dont like the style or just their interperatation of the style. I know Ive had abby dubbles Ive liked alot,not this.

Bottle picked up in Milwaukee about a month ago - this beer right here - this is how you do dubbel - nose is fantastic - rich maltiness (toffee, treacle), raisin, date, tamarind, cinnamon, nutmeg, light baked apple tartness - carbonation is pretty full, and a little rough at first, but becomes a bit softer and creamier as it sits - lightly bitter up front, followed by toasty malt richness, caramelized sugar, hazelnut, cookie/dough, raisin, whiskey - spicy finish, with moderate alcohol warmth - I dig this.

Very nice malty ale with a Belgium yeast note, medium brown pour with a very nice tan head, nice lacing. After warming a bit a very nice spicey aftertaste. Got mine straight from the brewery and enjoying it on their new patio area. Cheers New Glaurus , nice job.

Pours very dark brown with a thick tan head...excellent retention and lacing. Aroma has subtle fruit and roastiness...hints of underlying clove and allspice. Flavor has fruitiness up front and then firm roastiness...more hoppy than many dubbels ive had...faint leather and mild booze. Mouthfeel is medium/full and silky smooth with a dry roasty/fruity/hoppy finish.

16.9oz bottle, shared by phaleslu. Mostly clear amber red / brown color. Thin off-white head. Some loose dots of lace. Softer, lighter carbonation. Medium to bigger body. More dry finish. Some caramel, spicy, kind of cardboardy flavor. Some dark fruit. Bigger bitter taste, light sweet. Some spiciness in the flavor. Something thin about it. Not the best American strong ale, tastes a little bit off, but still drinkable.

500ml bottle. Pours dark amber brown with a large foamy sudsy khaki head that slowly fades to a film and lacing. Aroma has dark fruit some clove bubblegum nuts and malt. Taste is bitter with some spice like clove subtle banana roasted malt and nutty bread. Palate is thin to medium with a fizzy carbonation and finishes dry. Very happy I stumbled upon this today!

500 ml bottle from friends recent trip to Wisconsin- thanks Dan, Caroline, and Gretchen! Pours a hazy amber-gold with a small off-white head. Notes of caramel, earth, leaves, toffee, nuts, dried fruits, sugar, and a weird wet dog-like note that threw this one off for me. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a coating mouthfeel. Very odd beer.

Dark fruit and maple with hints of more maple. Tastes great with lots of Carmel malt. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml bottle to snifter (shared by phaleslu). Looks good; a semi-transparent caramel with off-white lacing. Smells solid; Belgian yeast and malt with notes of caramel and dark fruit. Tastes like it smells with a solid mouthfeel. Enjoyable.
pour is an amber with a small head..Nose is nutty, earth, light sweetness, bitter, dead leaves..Taste is dark fruit, spices, brown sugar, nutty earth, roast..

50cl bottle: pours a clear deep amber mahogany with a well-lacing froth of beige head. Has a sweet biscuity doughy dark caramel malty nose. Starts with good fullness and sweet dark malts with a touch of dark fruits and authentic Belgian yeast before a drier toasted finish. True to style and enjoyable.

Dark red with a foamy off-white head, abundant lacing and carbonation. Nose is mainly plum/fruits, caramel, figs, spices, licorice, cloves and malts. Flavor has a strong caramel and plum flavor upfront, followed by cloves, spices, licorice and malts. Body is moderate in weight and fairly light in carbonation. A robust and flavorful beer overall, worth seeking out if you are able to!
Not used to NG making a Belgian Strong Ale, I must say though one of my favorite micro brews (I am from Wisconsin btw) I was very impressed by this beer. Once again NG never fails.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, dark brownish black pour with lacing off white head, aroma brought notes of lots of dark fruits, cocoa powder, chocolate, hints of spice, slight red fruits as well. Taste is a nice mix of red fruits, nice candied nuts, hints of oak, slight spice, biscuit, hints of earth, touch of caramel and molasses, finishing sweet, sightly bitter. Tasty stuff!

Very fine beer. Poured at a good temperature with a giant, light tan, foamy, frothy, sudsy head that settled a bit slow and some lace. Color is a clear brown with some amber highlights and lots large bubble trails. Aroma is first bananas, then malt and a little other fruit, yeast. Flavor is very smooth, similar to nose, nice balance between sweet, bitter, and tang. Body is perfect; full, round, yet enough edge to keep it satisfying and interesting at the same time. The finish is like all those qualities that taper off moderately. Dont know how strong it is, but seems like I could drink a load of it. Happily.

I personally have had every Trappist beer, and just recently got to try Westvleteren 12. One of my favorite biers is St. Bernardus Abt 12, and I will that New Glarus Anniversary Strong Ale is as good if not better then the other Belgian Strong Dark biers (quads) that I have tried. 

I grabbed one this weekend and wasnt expecting much, since this was New Glarus first time brewing a big beer like this. I was very surprised at how good it was. I am now on the hunt to grab several more of these to throw in my cellar. Hats off to New Glarus! Cheers!
Bottle from chase! Pours amber with low head, aroma is sweet malt, taste is very smooth and rich, nice brew!

Deep brown pour w/ a tall thick light tan head with thick lacing. Aroma starts out quite sweet slightly syruppy hints of a light spice and a tiny hint of bubblegum. Reminiscent of a big sweet dubbel. Avg body with an overly aggressive carbonation. Flavor is lightly yeasty spicy some peppers and a hint of alcohol in the swallow. A nice beer, not in a style I tend to love though.
500ml bottle thanks to Ghostface. Pours a dark hazy brown with large tan head. Black cherry, wood, malt and candied sugar taste. Great beer. Extremely drinkable.
(500ml bottle) Pours a clear amber body with a medium off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, nuts, earth, toffee, and grass. Flavor of caramel, nuts, banana, roasted grain, peat, and raisins.

Poured dark brown feom the bottle with rich aromas of dark pitted fruit, light spuce, some earth and a touch of chocolate. Flavors are the same as aromas a light boozy burn in the aftertaste, rich flavors and enjoyable.
Bottle via trade with burgy - thanks! Murky brown pour. Lots of fig and plum, rich and warm. Slight nut but not a ton. Really good brew!

Pours a dark brown color with a good head.

The aroma is very rich and sweet, lightly spicy with good fruity notes featuring lots of pear, cherry, & fig. There is and a touch more banana than I would normally dig in a beer like this. Fairly inviting.

The flavor is chocolaty and rich, lots of warming booziness, lots of nice spice & licorice. Some good nutty notes, but not maybe as much nuttiness as typical in a Dubbel. Its not overly sweet, has a nice light bitterness throughout, and has some good licorice notes. 

Most defiantly somewhere stylistically in the balance between Dubbel & Quad... pretty cool beer.

Purchased at Discount Liquors in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed at home prior to seeing the band Toys That Kill. Appearance is a very dark brown with a rich slightly off white head that laces to the glass. Aroma is very rich in dark fruit, plum, caramel syrupy malt, its one of those brews that probably brings about more elements in the nose if its aged appropriately. Taste goes down with a bit of spice and a light burn, also goes down dry. Theres a lot going on with this one and its an interesting brew but not the easiest to drink, wouldve rather shared this one and had less to imbibe.
Dark Brown with white head. Tons of spicy sour spice but kind of a flat yeasty taste. Did not enjoy this one.

Bottled. Slight hazy color, short off-white head. Aroma of toasted malt, bit fruity, bit spicy, bit metallic. Bit too much yeast esters, although they are not that spicy, but more fruity. Bit sweet, bit dry. In taste its more spicy of cardemom or something. Not my kind of beer. Lacks some chocolat notes.

Bottle. Brownish pour with off white head. Nose of caramel, yeast, and dark fruit. Taste is bready with a similar profile to the nose. A little boozy. Fairly full bodied. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Goldenish color, spicy smell. Pretty tasty, pretty smooth but a little bit of alcohol bite on the end, time will do this one some favors. Nice spicy Belgian note as well, quite a bit of sweetness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
500ml to chalice shared. Deep dark mahogany color. Minimal cloudiness. Malty and spicy. On par with many things I had in Belgium.
Many thanks to Skyview! Brown color with a medium head. Aroma of candi sugar. Metallic taste. Slight malt character and brown sugar. Maybe an odd bottle, but very non-descript.

Bottle. Pours cloudy brown with a large beige creamy head with nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, spice, clove, toffee, anise. Flavor much the same, light to medium sweet, lemon zest, minimal bitterness. Full body, creamy mouthfeel, some alcohol warming. A bit too spiced for my personal preference.

500mL Bottle. Hot banana and bubblegum nose. Spicy yeasts start and prickly and warm palate, with bananas foster, cooked cream, and heavily boozed fruitcake. I want to like this, but I cant get there. The Belgian yeast just aint right. It leaves a slightly biting, kind of harsh phenolic sensation. Way too warm. Definitely needs to settle a little bit. Maybe its just too green, but it certainly isnt that stellar of an example of the style now. I appreciate the dryness and the juicyfruit finish, but the front end of the palate is heavy on harsh phenols and overly fruit esters that put what should be a more delicate malt structure out of balance. It does manage a graceful, really textured finish with juiciness, malt brownness and the right nip of sugar. Too bad about the phenols up front.

500mL bottle, courtesy of New Glarus. Thanks! Pours a dark, cola-brown color with a slight ruby hue; light-tan head with solid retention and nice lacing. A bit of warming alcohol in the aroma (nothing rough), along with caramel and dried-fruit sweetness, some brown sugar and clove bitterness, and a touch of white pepper and salinity. Medium-full body; lively, fine-bubbled carbonation; excellent texture (up there with the dialed-in Belgians), with slight roughness from white pepper and cloves at the forefront; overall, though, very much a generous, layered dubbel-like beer: dried fruits, nice caramelization, none of that cola-focused nonsense one often gets from U.S. renditions; dialing back those phenols at the front would let the rounder elements open up a bit more, but this is nice as is. Definitely a touch of vinous heat as it warms. Lasting finish show that clove and white-pepper bitterness lingering, along with a bit of toasty malts and brown sugar. Solid stuff, for sure.
Dark brown pour, light brown head. Smoke, malt, caramel, toffee, dried fruit, chewy beer.,
Mild smoke, pungent caramel malt, grapes, a touch astringent. Sweetened on the palate, a little boozy, caramelized malt again.

(500ml bottle thanks to brystmar) clear medium amber, meringue like tan head. Nose of mesquite smoke, raisin, cedar/oaky. Taste of raisin, scotch/peaty, medicinal, very herbal, bitter and odd. Dont like it.

Bottle @ a recent bottle share... Poured deep, dark, ruby/red with a thin head. Malty aroma. Malty and worty sweet. A whole lot of sweetness o on this one. Toasted grains and toffee sugars with some fermented flavored yeast and dark fruit esters for a touch of complexity. Overall though, nothing too interesting here.
Bottle. Pour is a dark amber/brown, some white head. Belgian stuff, dark fruits, spice on the nose and tongue. Ends a little boozy but its good. A year or two could make this bitter possibly.

Brownish red color with a small, light tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel malts, light roast, spices, and alcohol. Taste of dark fruits, sweeter caramel malts, some roastiness, spicy yeast, and sharp alcohol in the finish. Id guess > 10%.

500mL bottle split.

A: Dark brown with violet edges. Fluffy creme foam head. Decent legs.

N: Lots of raisin, prune, toffee, and biscuit. Nicely sweet with plenty of clove and esters.

T: Surprisingly bitter with a decent amount of caramel sweetness. Pretty good, but the hops could get dialed back.

M: Slightly sticky with a bready substance.

O: A good representation of the style for an American version, but Id prefer the real thing. Too many hops.
Bottle shared at the RateBeer Gallery event in SF. Crazy yeast stuff going on here, tons of bubblegum and banana, sweet and boozy. Reminds me a lot of Delirium Tremens.

Pours unclear quite dark amber with a big sandy colored head. The aroma brings some sweet and spicy Belgian malts and maybe some brown sugar and maple. The flavors are big, bringing sweet Belgian malts, spiciness tamed just enough, and a smooth settling ending, maybe a bit of maple there too.

Aromatics smell like straight fancy Bud heavy... WTF... Lots head in the appearance, like 4-5 fingers of thick, sticky white head! Nice amber colored beer. Taste is malt heavy with dark fruits. Palate is thick full and very lively with carbonation. Overall not bad, some what alcoholic. Aging may help! Plus the simplistic label is awesome!

shared by me with myself because Im really generous. Plums, brown sugar, toffee, black cherry,  caramel, and just a bit of grassy bitterness. Somewhat spicy finish with the alcohol, not distracting, fits perfect with the style. mildly sweet as well, again, no different than others Ive had. Good beer for the style I suppose, which isnt really my thing.

Bottle, ~20 ounces.  Malt and dried fruit in the aroma. Dark ruby brown color. Little foam, some residue lingering on top.  Taste is plums, dates, toasted barley and cereal. Low bitterness and sweet with some alcohol heat right away. My guess is that it weighs in at about 8.5-9%abv.  Medium bodied, low carbonation, strong flavor presence. Overall, not bad, but I had expected something more noteworthy and memorable, or they could have at least included a more descriptive label discussing why they chose this style and what ingredients they selected to celebrate their anniversary.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, long lasting half inch head and an aroma of candi sugar fragrant plums.  Flavor is also nice rich plums, slightly dry candi sugar, hints of caramel, nuts and a little toffee.  Really nice, glad a I have a few more bottles of this.

Bottle @ MPLS LOL. Thanks to Jeff! Pours a hazy brown appearance with a tan head. Fairly spicy, candy sugar, caramel, light chocolate, plum, well carbonated aroma. Nutmeg, banana, apple, caramel, spicy flavor. Good but not my favorite NG

500ml Bottle thanks to joshmcg000. Dark brown pour with a 2 finger, creamy, soapy and slightly chunky beige head that becomes creamier as time goes on and leaves very nice wavy sheets of lacing. Aroma of big caramel, lots of light and dark fruity esters, banana, nice perfume fruity hops, chocolate, toast, clove heavy sweet bread spice,  sweet floral and light earthy notes. Flavor is chocolate, sweet bread crust and dark fruit up front, then some clove and other sweet bread spice, bready and raw yeast, muscovado sugar, light vinous notes, a sweet fruit wood smokiness a hint of toasted wood, and spicy, citrus and pine hops to the finish along with a spicy, earthy and lightly mineral fade. Medium body with a creamy, neutral finish, moderate strength, blanketing and pleasantly smooth carbonation, with a still creamy, but off dry finish. Fantastic all around. Easily one of my favorite Dubbels.
500 ml. bottle.  Pours reddish brown with a nice biege head.  Aroma of fruit, malt, caramel, and yeast.  Taste is dark fruit, caramel, yeast, spice, and malt.  Excellent!

Pours slightly hazy red, very active carbonation and pillowy off white head. Aroma is spicey yeast, bananna, clove. Very spicy, lots of big banana yeast flavor. Tastes almost like there is some rye on the malt side to. Some bitterness on the back end. I drank a little of this a few weeks ago and didnt get any skunky taste. Drinking a bottle thats been in my fridge for about a month now it has a little skunkyness to it at first that fades after a few drinks...Weird and maybe cause I kept it in fridge to long, should have kept it warm.Other than that little bit of alcohol burn. Pretty nicely balanced and tasty. And definitely strong, especially as it warms up. Very curious what the actual ABV is as I cant find it anywhere.

Split bottle with SHERM1016.  Thanks.  Pours a rich mahogany brown with moderate head.  Nose and initial taste is filled with spices and cookie baking smells....hops balance with yeast.  Cloves and fruit abound.  Lingering cloves and bitter / hoppy finish.  Wonderful.

Bottle. Pours deep mahogany with thick foamy light brown head. Good lacing as the head diminishes. Nose is spicy hops with fruit overtones of orange marmalade. Some mild herbal notes, as well. Flavor is slightly hop forward - lively herbal bitter notes jump around the edges of the tongue. Hops are well balanced with clean and well-structured grain flavors of the malt. Aftertaste is dominated by black pepper-like hop flavor, a slowly receding bitterness and lingering toffee malt flavors.

Poured from 500ml bottle, pours a murky brown with a red hue in the light, a thick off white head that seemed to stay around forever, nice lacing, aroma has a decent amount of yeast mixed in with some fruity and spices, the flavor has a nice amount of dark fruit and yeast notes on the front end with a fruity finish, some bread notes in the finish as well, seems a little hot, others have already said it, but in a few months this might be a little more mellow and nice, pretty good though.

500 ml bottle from the Hilltop Brewery (New Glarus, WI). Pours a deep brownish ruby pour, dark decadent reddish and brown glow, mellow haze. Some more brownish copper glow on the edges shows some darker glow. A cakey tannish head atop stays large, remains a good layer, and laces well. Aromas offer fruity esters, banana bread, and toasty malts. Carmelized, some brown sugar, toffee, and touches of dried fruit. Esters and yeast show some strength as it warms, bready and biscuity, sweeter touches of vanilla, firm esters, banana bread, a touch of cocoa. Initial is fuller bodied, good toast, spice and yeast move into caramel, toffee, some brown sugar. Growing yeast presence shows banana, pear, a bit of red fruit. Body lets up more as we start moving on. Biscuits, toffee, and toast. A waft of cocoa, vanilla, spice. Firm and fuller body offers more fruit into the middle. A touch of red fruit, yeast, spice, some good spiciness as you round the corner. Some stickiness, gentle heat to let you know what this is on the backend and into the finish. Pretty well done, very fruity as you move into the middle and backend. Pretty solid offering, better spice and yeast, some heat on the backend with some dryness make this a bit more interesting. Front and middle and sweeter, richer estery fruit presence and thicker chewy malt presence. Backend makes this solid though. Nose is more fruity. Beer looks great. Nice. Where its not my favorite style or suited to my personal tastes, its pretty well done. Cheers to 20 years!

Bottle. Pours a deep dark mahogany brown with a foamy off white head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Aromas of dark fruits, bananas, candied sugar, and caramel malts. Taste is similar with spice from the yeast and some nice dry herbal bitterness. Not quite usually my thing, but this was a very well produced Dubbel.
user_location: Menasha Red Light District, Wisconsin, USA

text:
Bottle from Casanovas, dark ruby brown pour with a decent white head. Aroma of bananas, dark fruit and a lot of yeast. Taste is tons of yeast, slight clove and some dark fruit, tingly mouth feel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From bottle at Davis BeerFest. Pours reddish brown with a nice beige head and a candi sugar aroma. There is a carbonated dark malt flavor with some plum, candi sugar and a bitter finish. A nice dubbel.

500ml bottle from Discount in Waukesha. Pours a faintly reddish brown with a foamy brownish-white head leaving a lot of lacing. Aroma has spicy yeast, banana, sweet malts and fruits & nuts. Taste is of strong spiciness, sweet caramel, cloves, heavy brown sugar. Yeasty and sweet, quite thick and dry. Some alcohol presence. Finishes sweetly spicy with some length. Interesting take on whatever style this is. Seems that it would age well - may have to find another.
Bottle from Casanova Liquors.  I didnt like this one as much as others did.  Had a bit of a funky aftertaste to me.  Complexity is definitely there though.

500mL thanks to katie and sammi. Pours clear red tea with healthy red tinted beige foam. Big retention, complete sheets of lace. Stickier abbey quadrupel nose with dark cherry, something like candied blood orange. Taste is pretty much abbey quadrupel with anise, something like wormwood, dark cherry. Dry spices, wood dryness in finish. Some lactic acid balance in backend. Different, yummy.

Thin white head. Deep red color. Sweet, dark fruit aroma, complex and yeasty. Malty and robust. This is a seriously good strong ale. Spicy and tasty. Very very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a mahogany color with a medium pillowy off-white head that leaves sheets of lacing.  Aroma is fig, plum, dark fruit, candied sugar, and nutty malts.  Rather smooth mouthfeel that leaves a nice warming sensation.  Taste is raisin, dark fruit, candied sugar, with some caramel malts on the finish.  Not my favorite style but well balanced and drinkable.

Pours to a deep mahogany brown body with a rocky off white tan head. The aroma is candi sugar, cola, treacle,  banana,  clove, and tobacco.  Flavors are extremely similar to westmalle dubbel.  Earthy tobacco,  malt, molasses, yeasts, bananas, and clove. A light peppery alcohol actually rounds this beer out, but Im looking forward to throwing a little age on this beer. Medium full body bur clean. Velvety texture.

Enjoyed via a bottle from Sendiks in Whitefish Bay. Pours a sable brown with a lacy tan head that clings over an inch up the glass. The smell is cola with a touch of grassy effervescence. It is smooth and silky on the palette with some of that same cola flavor along with dry, bitter hops. There is a slight booziness that will most likely mellow with age. I expect it to only improve as time goes on.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark brown, near black, with a big fluffy tan head.   Aroma of candi sugar, belgian yeast, mild sweetness.  Lots of fruit in the aroma.  Banana, cherries, some berries.  Flavor is intoxicating, rich belgian yeast, strong toffee, caramel, and brown sugar notes.  Medium bodied, near perfect carbonation.  Fantastic mouthfeel.  Finishes mildly sweet.  Absolutely fantastic beer.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2014 Elegant clear dark ruby brown. Rich, frothy, lasting off-white head. Thick lace. Aroma is voluptuous, sweet; dark fruit, banana, caramel, spices, yeast, banana bread... Flavor syncs up, add a touch more alcohol. Soft and creamy. Medium body with a spicy, clean, bitter finish along with some alcohol warming. This is a Dubbel worthy of high praise. (5/25/13)
UPDATE (12/31/14) After over a year and half of aging this has gotten even better. Still carbonated, soft, and creamy. Even richer and more complex caramel, toffee, fruit, and bread, and spice. Alcohol hides a little more. Still has a light bitterness. Luscious. This has really come together wonderfully.

Aroma is initially hard to decipher.  Malt for sure.  A little sugar, maybe caramel.  A little sweet, but not really like candy.

Taste-bananas, malt, sugar, caramel.  Fairly smooth, but occasionally bitter.  Taste dissipates quickly, but then comes back with a little tinge in the back of the throat.

Never ending head.

500mL bottle.  Poured clear, coppery-amber with a dense, creamy beige head.  The aroma picked up nutty notes, toffee, and marzipan with earthy and lemony-herbal accents.. banana and clove esters emerged as it warmed.. spicy and quite yeasty by the time it got to room temperature, but very well balanced.  The flavor found nutty notes, chocolate, and aged caramel at the core with banana, clove, and fruity yeast around.. spicy yeast impression on the finish paired with a misplaced green hop presence.  Medium-bodied and quite bitter/spicy on the palate.. a hair too sharp and bitter, but otherwise a tasty and interesting brew.

Clear dark amber pour, soft white head - tons of lacing on this one. Nose is dark fruit, some belgian spiciness and a little alcohol. Very good, but a touch hot on the finish. Will be interested to see how time treats it.

** This is a dark strong. Dark burgundy with a nice foam. About a quarter inch but is hangs around. Aroma is malt, caramel and yeast. Big malt and caramel flavor. Some dried fruit and a little coffee in the finish. Maybe tobacco I cant decide. Well carbonated. This is an excellent beer! World class. Very limited release but if you can get some you?re in for a treat.

Murky brown pour with amber-orange edges and off-white head.  Nose is yeasty baked banana bread, light pear, and faint bubblegum.  Flavor is gentle banana and yeast with a pronounced toasted biscuit and light roasted malt.  Fairly dry finish with residual burnt toast and faint banana.  Carbonation is rather prickly.  A nice offering.  Cheers and congrats!

500ml bottle - Pours murky brown with a thick foamy tan head. Lots of plum and dark bread on the nose, with some sweet yeastiness and some light candi sugar. A bit of boozy warmth. Taste is sweet and a bit of oaky, bready booziness. The dark fruit is a bit muted and the bread is dark and a bit bitter. A bit of spice. Smooth and soft in the mouth. A bit sharp...I think a little time will help this one, but it was still pretty tasty.

500ml bottle, purchased at Discount Liquor Milwaukee. Pours a deep, dark brown color with a huge tan head that recedes pretty quickly, leaving a bunch of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is Belgian yeast, dark fruit, raisin, molasses. Medium on the palate with soft, creamy carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, malty, bready, nutty, some spicy Belgian yeast, a little bit of alcohol heat, with a sweet, malty finish.  I really like this beer.  I would like to do a side by side with Westmalle Dubbel, just to see how it stands up.

3rd rating.  Deep cherry brown body.  Foamy, beige head laces up the glass.  Sweet dark fruit aroma, relatively classic and true to style.  Really full, expressed fruity yeast tones.  Has more of a Trappist depth, maybe lacking the effervescence/mouthfeel though.  Quite a phenomenal Dubbel, this can hang with the big boys.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2016 500ml bottle. Pours a beautiful dark plumb color with a frothy tan head that leaves some really nice lacing. Smell is spicy yeast, banana, dark fruits, bready malt, and sugar sweetness. The flavor is similar but better. Rich malt flavors, not too cloyingly sweet. It is fruity but spicy, light herbal bitterness in the finish. Havent really had a US Belgian-styled ale that was quite this good. Wasnt expecting it to be this tasty.

Well it looks like I might be the first one ever to publish a review of New Glarus 20th Anniversary Strong Ale. As a liquor store guy, you have to enjoy the perks of the job sometimes! The word is this is extremely limited and rationed throughout the state so make sure you grab it while you can. 

This one pours a dark amber color with a foamy beige head. The aroma is very yeasty with hints of bread, tart fruit, and banana. Very inviting with its traditional Belgian characteristics. 

Holy cow is this beer smooth! To compliment the smooth texture is a rich, deep flavor that is very well balanced. Yeast, caramel malt, banana, and citrus are all present and very tasty. This is a slow sipper that delivers a lot of great flavor. It finishes sweet with a great malty after taste.  The lacing it leaves behind is pretty impressive too!

This is a brew well worthy of being a 20th Anniversary celebration release. This ranks pretty high with me amongst other New Glarus beers. Im sure this will earn a place in the hearts of many beer lovers. All I can say is I will look forward to a delicious 25th Anniversary brew 5 years from now! -Chris Lemke of WisconsinBrewReview.com
